FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE KINEMATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility: W.C. Gretter & Sons, Inc.; Harper, Iowa Contact: Frank W. Gretter II

     Phone:    641-635-2 174

     1.   Facility Policy

The owners, management and employees of W.C. Gretter & Sons, Inc. at their Harper, Iowa
location (the facility) are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous
ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire
department, or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people
and the environment.

     2.   Facility Information

The primary activity at the facility is the storage and sale of fertilizer to area farmers. Anhydrous
ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application for crop production nutrients.
Anhydrous ammonia is stored at the facility in three (3) storage tanks 2 @15,000 gallons each
and I @ 12,000 gallons and 16 nurse tanks @ 1,000 gallons each. The maximum quantity stored
would be about 251,430 pounds.

     3.   Worst Case and Alternate Case Release Scenarios

A) The Worst Case Scenario would be the release of the total contents of a storage tank released
as gas over a period of 10 minutes. The maximum quantity released would be about 50,000
pounds, which represents the volume of the largest storage tank at 85 percent capacity as limited
by design standards. The distance to the end point (point of dispersion to 200 parts per million, or
ppm) is about 3.4 miles.

B) The Alternate Case Release Scenario, based on the five-year accident history (or the most
likely potential incident), is a release from a rupture disk / relief valve failure. The distance to the
endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is about 0.19 miles. The maximum quantity released
would be about 1,000 pounds.

     4.   Accidental Release Prevention Program

The facility has been reviewed for general compliance with the provisions of "Safety
Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-6 1. 1", publish

ed by The
American National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI) and the standards of the United States
Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and
Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". 'The ANSI Standard has been adopted by reference by Iowa
Administrative Code Part 2 I -Chapter 43-Rule 43. 6(200), "Standard for the Storage and
Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". The OSHA standard is referenced in the Registration Form
Section 8.3.b.

     5.   Five-Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have
caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge,
have resulted in on-site deaths, injuries' evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or
environmental damage.

     6.   Emergency Response Program

The facility has:

a. a written action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38; and

b. provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and community
right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

     7.   Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to
assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are no additional specific safety
recommendations regarding storage or use anhydrous ammonia for implementation at this time.
